articles.headline: G.O.P. Spending Hawks Defy Trump on the Debt Limit, Previewing More Clashes
articles.snippet: President-elect Donald J. Trump is known for his tight grip on members of his party, but the rare rejection of his demand to suspend the debt limit reflected a disconnect that could plague his policy agenda.
articles.abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump is known for his tight grip on members of his party, but the rare rejection of his demand to suspend the debt limit reflected a disconnect that could plague his policy agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: Something unusual happened this week after President-elect Donald J. Trump ordered House Republicans to back legislation raising the debt limit: Dozens refused.
articles.byline: By Catie Edmondson and Andrew Duehren

articles.headline: Congress Approves Spending Extension, Ending Shutdown Crisis
articles.snippet: The Senate passed the measure and sent it to President Biden’s desk, shortly after the midnight deadline for funding to lapse.
articles.abstract: The Senate passed the measure and sent it to President Biden’s desk, shortly after the midnight deadline for funding to lapse.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Senate approved a spending measure early Saturday to keep government money flowing through mid-March, sending it to President Biden for his signature and closing a chaotic endgame in Congress minutes after federal funding had lapsed.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Catie Edmondson

articles.headline: 3-Minute Christmas Market Rampage Shakes Germany
articles.snippet: At least five people, including a 9-year-old child, were killed in the attack, which took place in the eastern city of Magdeburg. The authorities are still seeking a motive.
articles.abstract: At least five people, including a 9-year-old child, were killed in the attack, which took place in the eastern city of Magdeburg. The authorities are still seeking a motive.
articles.lead_paragraph: It took an attacker just three minutes to kill five people and wound hundreds by ramming an S.U.V. into a crowded holiday market on Friday night, stunning Germany and shattering the peace of its Christmas season.
articles.byline: By Christopher F. Schuetze and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: Death on the Night Shift at Frozen Pizza Factories in Chicago
articles.snippet: Undocumented workers help feed America’s hunger for prepared foods, but some take jobs with staffing agencies that expose them to hazardous conditions.
articles.abstract: Undocumented workers help feed America’s hunger for prepared foods, but some take jobs with staffing agencies that expose them to hazardous conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a brilliant day three years ago, a grieving crowd gathered on the South Side of Chicago to bury Adewale Ezekiel Ogunyemi.
articles.byline: By Marcela Valdes, Churchill Ndonwie, Danielle Ivory, Steve Eder and Sebastián Hidalgo

articles.headline: Is ‘People Pleasing’ Giving You Money Problems? Here’s How to Fix Things.
articles.snippet: Spending money to avoid conflict or gain social acceptance can ruin your finances. Some self-reflection and support from professionals can help turn things around.
articles.abstract: Spending money to avoid conflict or gain social acceptance can ruin your finances. Some self-reflection and support from professionals can help turn things around.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hailey Magee often paid for drinks when she went out with friends, bought loved ones expensive dinners and picked up the tab on dates. During the holiday season, Ms. Magee purchased lavish gifts, even when she was on a tight budget.
articles.byline: By Juli Fraga and Connie Chang

articles.headline: From Liberal Icon to MAGA Joke: The Waning Fortunes of Justin Trudeau
articles.snippet: Canada’s prime minister gained global renown 10 years ago for his unabashedly progressive politics. But at home, voters turned sour on him long ago.
articles.abstract: Canada’s prime minister gained global renown 10 years ago for his unabashedly progressive politics. But at home, voters turned sour on him long ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: Justin Trudeau’s career is the stuff of 21st-century political drama, with an arc that has taken him from glamorous liberal standard-bearer to the butt of jokes by President-elect Donald J. Trump and his acolytes.

articles.headline: Hitting Home for the Holidays: A Jump in Egg Prices
articles.snippet: Costs have soared again amid a bird flu outbreak, bringing renewed attention to the fact that while inflation is cooling, prices are still elevated.
articles.abstract: Costs have soared again amid a bird flu outbreak, bringing renewed attention to the fact that while inflation is cooling, prices are still elevated.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans stocking up on holiday cooking essentials may be greeted with an unwelcome surprise in the grocery aisles: higher prices for eggs, spurred by an intensifying bird flu outbreak.

articles.headline: Deception and Betrayal: Inside the Final Days of the Assad Regime
articles.snippet: President Bashar al-Assad, who wielded fear and force over Syria for more than two decades, fled the country under the cover of night — and a fake political address.
articles.abstract: President Bashar al-Assad, who wielded fear and force over Syria for more than two decades, fled the country under the cover of night — and a fake political address.
articles.lead_paragraph: As rebels advanced toward the Syrian capital of Damascus on Dec. 7, the staff in the hilltop Presidential Palace prepared for a speech they hoped would lead to a peaceful end to the 13-year civil war.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Farnaz Fassihi, Christina Goldbaum and Hwaida Saad

articles.headline: A Cultural Casualty of the War in Ukraine: ‘The Nutcracker’
articles.snippet: Lithuania’s national opera house had stopped showing Tchaikovsky’s 1892 masterpiece in solidarity with Ukraine over the war with Russia. Then a new minister expressed fondness for the Russian composer, igniting a furor.
articles.abstract: Lithuania’s national opera house had stopped showing Tchaikovsky’s 1892 masterpiece in solidarity with Ukraine over the war with Russia. Then a new minister expressed fondness for the Russian composer, igniting a furor.
articles.lead_paragraph: Unimpressed by the substitute for Tchaikovsky’s “Nutcracker,” the mother and her young daughter left at the intermission, a small protest over a decision by the opera house not to perform the Russian composer’s Christmas classic.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Jenny Gross

articles.headline: Why Is It So Hard to Make a Robot Chef?
articles.snippet: Restaurants are experimenting with automation. But in the kitchen, human labor is hard to replace.
articles.abstract: Restaurants are experimenting with automation. But in the kitchen, human labor is hard to replace.
articles.lead_paragraph: The robot in the kitchen was upset.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Brian Karlsson

articles.headline: Behold! ‘Christmas Adam’ Is Born.
articles.snippet: First there was Christmas Eve … and then a new celebration was created.
articles.abstract: First there was Christmas Eve … and then a new celebration was created.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some 2,000 years ago, on a holy night in Bethlehem as stars were brightly shining, a young woman gave birth to a baby and laid him in a manger. The baby Jesus was a thrill of hope for a weary world, the gospel story goes, and Christians ever since remember his birth in the candlelight of Christmas Eve.

articles.headline: Germany Tries to Untangle Complex Profile of Market Attack Suspect
articles.snippet: The authorities said they were struggling to understand the motives behind ramming a car into a Christmas market in the eastern city of Magdeburg, which left a 9-year-old boy among the five dead.
articles.abstract: The authorities said they were struggling to understand the motives behind ramming a car into a Christmas market in the eastern city of Magdeburg, which left a 9-year-old boy among the five dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: A frequent critic on social media of the German government, as well as of radical Islam. A reclusive neighbor who appeared to live most of his life on the internet. A man whose extreme political postings online prompted an alert to Germany from Saudi Arabia.
articles.byline: By Christopher F. Schuetze and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: Organized Looting Throws Gaza Deeper Into Chaos
articles.snippet: Gangs are filling a power vacuum left by Israel in some parts of southern Gaza, hijacking desperately needed aid for Palestinian residents.
articles.abstract: Gangs are filling a power vacuum left by Israel in some parts of southern Gaza, hijacking desperately needed aid for Palestinian residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hazem Isleem, a Palestinian truck driver, was passing through the ruins of southern Gaza last month with a truckload of aid when armed looters ambushed his convoy.
articles.byline: By Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman

articles.headline: Honda and Nissan Aim to Merge as Global Competition Bears Down
articles.snippet: Japan’s second- and third-largest automakers hope the $50 billion deal would help them catch up with Tesla and China’s BYD in electric vehicles and advanced software.
articles.abstract: Japan’s second- and third-largest automakers hope the $50 billion deal would help them catch up with Tesla and China’s BYD in electric vehicles and advanced software.
articles.lead_paragraph: Honda Motor and Nissan Motor are exploring a merger to create one of the world’s largest auto groups as they seek to better position themselves for the expensive technological transition reshaping the automotive industry.

articles.headline: Biden Commutes 37 Death Sentences Ahead of Trump’s Plan to Resume Federal Executions
articles.snippet: Those affected by the president’s action on Monday are still subject to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole. Three men will remain on federal death row.
articles.abstract: Those affected by the president’s action on Monday are still subject to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole. Three men will remain on federal death row.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden on Monday commuted the sentences of nearly all prisoners on federal death row, sparing the lives of 37 men just a month before Donald J. Trump will return to the Oval Office with a promise to restart federal executions.

articles.headline: Netflix Hopes to Recapture ‘Squid Game’ Magic
articles.snippet: The success of the show’s first season surprised Netflix executives, reaffirming the company’s global strategy.
articles.abstract: The success of the show’s first season surprised Netflix executives, reaffirming the company’s global strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Los Angeles, 1,600 people ran a 4.56-kilometer race to win admission to an early screening of the show.
articles.byline: By Nicole Sperling and Jin Yu Young

articles.headline: Under Pressure, Telegram Pulls Off an Elusive Milestone: A Profit
articles.snippet: Even as Telegram faces legal scrutiny and grapples with billions in debt, it is set to be profitable for the first time as it tries cryptocurrencies, subscriptions and ads.
articles.abstract: Even as Telegram faces legal scrutiny and grapples with billions in debt, it is set to be profitable for the first time as it tries cryptocurrencies, subscriptions and ads.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent months, Telegram, the lightly moderated social media app, has held discussions with investors who lent it more than $2 billion. The goal: to reassure them that the company remains a viable bet after its founder, Pavel Durov, was arrested in France in August on charges related to illicit activities on the platform.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: House Ethics Panel Report Accuses Gaetz of ‘Regularly’ Paying for Sex and Using Drugs
articles.snippet: The Florida Republican resigned from the House and withdrew as Donald J. Trump’s attorney general pick in the weeks before the report’s release.
articles.abstract: The Florida Republican resigned from the House and withdrew as Donald J. Trump’s attorney general pick in the weeks before the report’s release.
articles.lead_paragraph: The House Ethics Committee said on Monday that its lengthy investigation had found that former Representative Matt Gaetz, Republican of Florida, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s initial choice for attorney general, had regularly paid women for sex, had sex with an underage girl and used illegal drugs.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater, Maggie Haberman and Robert Draper
